description.narrative:
The Goal of the Capfish/FOSTER project is to improve the socio-economic conditions of the fishing communities and environmental sustainability of the (Western) Tonle Sap Biosphere Reserve (TSBR) through community-centered interventions reaching over 200000 women, men and children in Cambodia. The Capfish/FOSTER Project led by Oxfam and 14 partners has 3 Objectives: 1)Fishing communities in the Tonle Sap have increased access to safe water supply, hygiene and sanitation services2) Vulnerable and poor girls and boys are provided with increased availability and accessibility to education and can successfully transition through school 3) Fishing communities in the Tonle Sap have developed sustainable alternative livelihoods
Almost 100,000 people live in dense floating communities on Cambodia’s Tonle Sap Lake and during the low water dry season, many experience poor health as their local ambient water becomes contaminated and often septic. The Foster project ensures fishing communities in the Tonle Sap have increased access to safe water supply, hygiene and sanitation services. Working with innovative award winning Social Enterprises such as Wetland Works ( WW) that provides sustainable hygiene and sanitation solution (HPods ) The project "Introducing Sanitation Through Awareness, Demand Creation and Local Market-driven Supply of HandyPod Treatment Systems in Floating and Floodplain Communities on Tonle Sap Lake, Cambodia" is implemented by Wetland Works . This project introduces sanitation to climate-vulnerable people living in remote floating and floodplain environs of the West Tonle Sap lake. Using Wetland Works HandyPod treatment system floating household’s wastewater can be contained and treated to a high grey water standard, allowing ambient water outside the Pod to be healthful. Improving local ambient waterquality as well as making cleaner, safer water for household use, fosters better health among families with children and a more robust surrounding natural environment for economically valuable fish larvae.

participating-org.narrative:
Wetlands Work! provides sustainable solutions for water treatment with a focus on harnessing natural microbial processes. We designand build simple systems promoting an eco-friendly, local-market and circular economy strategy that improves health, hygiene, protects fragile ecosystems and creates new local jobs.
- Background of counterpart: Wetlands Work! initiated sanitation research and design work in 2008 and in 2011 became a registered Cambodian social enterprise. WW!’s innovative work has been recognized with awardsfrom the Civil Society Water Sanitation and Hygiene Fund, RELX Environment Award, Global Sanitation Fund and The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation’s Global Stars in Health Award.
Goals: 1. Create WW! business development capacityto provide services globally. 2. Diversify WW!’s HandyPod sanitation technology and supply strategy to environments additional to floating, floodplain and high groundwater conditions, such as tropical island communities, tourist beaches and remote ecotourist facilities where pit latrines are inappropriate. WW emphasizes locally-owned, market-driven and circular economics, making productive use wherever possible of urine as anorganic fertilizer and cured fecal sludge as a soil supplement. WW keeps its tech designs simple for low maintenance and scale-up in challenging socio-economic and physical environments. 3. Market our WW! constructed wetland designs for industrial wastewater treatment, commercial treatment and hospital discharges. 4. Promote awareness of wetland natural service values including wetlands as public infrastructure for water quality.
Vision: WW! envisions all poor, low wealth people living with proper sanitation, regardless of the landscape conditions they live in. WW!’s sanitation vision is for healthy children and adults, and good environmental water quality that supports robust aquatic ecosystems with biodiverse fauna and flora.
Mission: WW!’s mission is to provide public access to HandyPod-adapted sanitation technology, while initiating national-level and community awareness of the primacy of sanitation benefits as well as the demand for sanitation – one that is supplied through sustainable WW!-trained local market-driven programming.
